Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Energy Efficient Process Design Alternatives
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project centers on new design process software for reducing energy use in chemical manufacturing. Commodity chemicals, plastics, polymers and other materials require large amounts of energy to make and the companies that manufacture these products make up the single largest group of energy consumers in the industrial sector in the U.S. and worldwide. Many opportunities for reducing energy consumption exist within the chemical, biochemical, and pharmaceutical industries, particularly in the area of chemical separations. The innovation has potential to provide customers with new capabilities for retrofitting existing facilities and/or new grass roots designs to reduce energy consumption, reduce operating costs, improve company profits, and simultaneously reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

This I-Corps project has at its core novel process design technology that is based on a combination of engineering, geometric, and optimization principles. The design software, and the technology on which it is based, can be used to reliably determine portfolios of feasible, energy efficient designs that meet specific process energy targets and can easily be combined with other methods that address heat exchange and chemical reaction. It allows the user to automatically and systematically explore a wide range of process alternatives, including processes with reaction, separation and recycle, those that involve hybrid separations, and/or process intensification. Unlike other currently available methods for the same task, this new technology guarantees that the resulting designs are feasible. The core technology has been extensively tested on a wide range of benchmark design examples in the open literature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project began with a needs assessment for software for analyzing and improving energy efficiency in the chemical and petroleum industry. After four weeks and approximately 40 interviews of researchers and practitioners in these industries it was determined that the need was not there, most likely due to advances in oil recovery methods that has resulted in a significant reduction in the price from almost $140/barrel in 2008 to a low of $33/barrel in 2016. Historical data for the price of oil per barrel information can be found at http://www.macrotrends.net/1369/crude-oil-price-history-chart. Therefore it was decided to shift the focus on software that analyzes and simulates all types of metabolism (from digesting the food we eat to cancer and vegan diets and everything in between) and to offer that software to the biotechnology, pharmaceutical, and medical industries.

 

The decision to shift focus was a good one. Although it took approximately five additional months of visiting companies and hospitals and over 100 interviews with workers in the biotechnology, pharmaceutical, and medical industries, the effort has paid off and has led to a very recent consulting contract with a large client (NYU Medical), which is currently under negotiation. NYU Medical has literally hundreds of practicing physicians that cover a wide range of treatments in all types of cancers as well as other diseases (Alzheimer's disease, diabetes, etc.) and  also a large group of medical researchers in areas such as biochemistry, oncology, radiology, and so on, all of whom can benefit from the metabolic pathway software offered by the PI. NYU Medical has great potential for many different and long term entrepreneurial opportunities: consulting, software licensing, sub-contracts on grants, and workshops.

 

The PI visited NYU Medical several times in the first five months of 2018 to cultivate a relationship. From the outset, the group of twenty plus people affiliated with the Metabolomics Interest Group were extremely impressed with the PI's software capabilities and saw immediate and countless applications throughout their research and medical facilities, including incorporation of the PI's software in their pathway data and visualization software system called Reactome (https://reactome.org/). They were so impressed that they have invited the PI to be a regular member of the group and to attend monthly meetings. All of this has the potential to lead to considerable long term entrepreneurial opportunities and the formation of a company.
